author: Mike Walters
title: Harry Redknapp says England must build their 2018 World Cup side around Dele Alli and Ross Barkley
text:
Harry Redknapp says England must build their 2018 World Cup side around Dele Alli and Ross Barkley The former Tottenham boss says lessons must be learned from the failure of the 'golden' generation Share Redknapp knows how England should line up in Russia (Photo: Getty Images)   
Harry Redknapp says England must learn from the ‘golden’ generation’s greatest failure by building their 2018 World Cup side around Dele Alli and Ross Barkley . 
None of Gareth Southgate’s predecessors managed to get the best out of Steven Gerrard and Frank Lampard as a pair when they should have been kings of the chessboard. 
Instead of harnessing their scoring power from midfield – Lampard and Gerrard scored 454 goals in club football between them - for a decade watching England was like a pawn movie with the sound turned down. 
Never one to blow his own trumpet where a whole brass band is available, Redknapp – who missed out on the England manager’s job to Roy Hodgson in 2012 – reckons he “would have done all right if I’d had the chance.” Harry Redknapp missed out on the England job in 2012 
In fairness, ‘Arry couldn’t have done much worse than getting knocked out of the World Cup inside a week and losing to Iceland at the Euros. 
But he would have given Gerrard and Lampard more of a gallop, and he is determined that England should not make the same mistake with Tottenham playmaker Alli and resurgent Everton midfielder Barkley. Gerrard and Lampard never truly clicked for England (Photo: The FA via Getty) 
“I’d pick them both,” said Redknapp, who turned 70 this month. “Why shouldn’t Barkley play in the same team as Alli? He’s 6ft tall, incredible build, and Dele Alli’s 6ft-plus, so we’re not talking about tiny little kids with no strength who can’t tackle and can’t defend. 
“Play your best players, find a way to include them in the England team, don’t fish for excuses to leave them out. 
“The pair of them can run all day, they can pass the ball, they can head it, they can shoot, they are box-to-box midfield players – they have got everything. Alli is a key man for England already (Photo: Reuters) 
“A few years ago we had Gerrard and Lampard, and it was only that people weren’t clever enough to get the best out of them. 
“OK, if you want a bit of insurance, you sit someone in between those two, you let them go higher up the pitch, arriving in the box – bang! What a fantastic pair. 
“Frank was getting 20 goals from midfield every year – if you get a striker who scores 20 in a season now it’s a miracle, isn’t it? Barkley is finding form again this term (Photo: Getty) 
“The other week I watched Manchester City play Tottenham, and when I looked at City’s team I thought, ‘Hang on, what are they doing? They are all fantastic footballers, but they haven’t got a ‘dog’ in midfield – who’s going to hold?’ 
“But they murdered Tottenham that day, they were absolutely fantastic – because they had people who can play. Too often we get blinded by the idea that you’ve got to have a holding midfielder, you’ve got to have a defensive anchor. 
“OK, so Chelsea have got the boy (N’Golo Kante) who sits in – but why can’t England play Barkley and Alli together?” 
Redknapp insists he is not bitter about missing the boat with England. But he would surely have gone further at major tournaments than Hodgson and lasted more than Sam Allardyce’s 67-day reign. Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
